◆ mysql_prune_stmt_list()

static void mysql_prune_stmt_list ( MYSQL *  mysql)
static

For use when the connection to the server has been lost (in which case the server has discarded all information about prepared statements associated with the connection).

Mark all statements in mysql->stmts by setting stmt->mysql= 0 if the statement has transitioned beyond the MYSQL_STMT_INIT_DONE state, and unlink the statement from the mysql->stmts list.

The remaining pruned list of statements (if any) is kept in mysql->stmts.

Parameters
mysqlpointer to the MYSQL object
Returns
none

sends a COM_CHANGE_USER command with a caller provided payload

Packet format:

Bytes Content

n user name - \0-terminated string n password 3.23 scramble - \0-terminated string (9 bytes) otherwise - length (1 byte) coded n database name - \0-terminated string 2 character set number (if the server >= 4.1.x) n client auth plugin name - \0-terminated string, (if the server supports plugin auth)

Return values
0ok
1error

◆ send_client_reply_packet()

static int send_client_reply_packet ( MCPVIO_EXT *  mpvio,
const uchar *  data,
int  data_len 
)
static

sends a client authentication packet (second packet in the 3-way handshake)

Packet format (when the server is 4.0 or earlier):

Bytes Content

2 client capabilities 3 max packet size n user name, \0-terminated 9 scramble_323, \0-terminated

Packet format (when the server is 4.1 or newer):

Bytes Content

4 client capabilities 4 max packet size 1 charset number 23 reserved (always 0) n user name, \0-terminated n plugin auth data (e.g. scramble), length (1 byte) coded n database name, \0-terminated (if CLIENT_CONNECT_WITH_DB is set in the capabilities) n client auth plugin name - \0-terminated string, (if CLIENT_PLUGIN_AUTH is set in the capabilities)

Return values
0ok
1error

202 {
203 #ifdef HAVE_POLL
204  struct pollfd ufds;

206  DBUG_ENTER("wait_for_data");
207 
208  DBUG_PRINT("info", ("polling"));
209  ufds.fd= fd;
210  ufds.events= POLLIN | POLLPRI;
211  if (!(res= poll(&ufds, 1, (int) timeout*1000)))
212  {
213  DBUG_PRINT("info", ("poll timed out"));
214  errno= EINTR;
215  DBUG_RETURN(-1);
216  }
217  DBUG_PRINT("info",
218  ("poll result: %d errno: %d revents: 0x%02d events: 0x%02d",
219  res, errno, ufds.revents, ufds.events));
220  if (res < 0 || !(ufds.revents & (POLLIN | POLLPRI)))
221  DBUG_RETURN(-1);
222  /*
223  At this point, we know that something happened on the socket.
224  But this does not means that everything is alright.
225  The connect might have failed. We need to retrieve the error code
226  from the socket layer. We must return success only if we are sure
227  that it was really a success. Otherwise we might prevent the caller
228  from trying another address to connect to.
229  */
230  {
231  int s_err;
232  socklen_t s_len= sizeof(s_err);
233 
234  DBUG_PRINT("info", ("Get SO_ERROR from non-blocked connected socket."));
235  res= getsockopt(fd, SOL_SOCKET, SO_ERROR, &s_err, &s_len);
236  DBUG_PRINT("info", ("getsockopt res: %d s_err: %d", res, s_err));
237  if (res)
238  DBUG_RETURN(res);
239  /* getsockopt() was successful, check the retrieved status value. */
240  if (s_err)
241  {
242  errno= s_err;
243  DBUG_RETURN(-1);
244  }
245  /* Status from connect() is zero. Socket is successfully connected. */
246  }
247  DBUG_RETURN(0);
248 #else
249  SOCKOPT_OPTLEN_TYPE s_err_size = sizeof(uint);
250  fd_set sfds;
251  struct timeval tv;
252  time_t start_time, now_time;
253  int res, s_err;
254  DBUG_ENTER("wait_for_data");
255 
256  if (fd >= FD_SETSIZE) /* Check if wrong error */
257  DBUG_RETURN(0); /* Can't use timeout */
258 
259  /*
260  Our connection is "in progress." We can use the select() call to wait
261  up to a specified period of time for the connection to suceed.
262  If select() returns 0 (after waiting howevermany seconds), our socket
263  never became writable (host is probably unreachable.) Otherwise, if
264  select() returns 1, then one of two conditions exist:
265 
266  1. An error occured. We use getsockopt() to check for this.
267  2. The connection was set up sucessfully: getsockopt() will
268  return 0 as an error.
269 
270  Thanks goes to Andrew Gierth <andrew@erlenstar.demon.co.uk>
271  who posted this method of timing out a connect() in
272  comp.unix.programmer on August 15th, 1997.
273  */
274 
275  FD_ZERO(&sfds);
276  FD_SET(fd, &sfds);
277  /*
278  select could be interrupted by a signal, and if it is,
279  the timeout should be adjusted and the select restarted
280  to work around OSes that don't restart select and
281  implementations of select that don't adjust tv upon
282  failure to reflect the time remaining
283  */
284  start_time= my_time(0);
285  for (;;)
286  {
287  tv.tv_sec = (long) timeout;
288  tv.tv_usec = 0;
289 #if defined(HPUX10)
290  if ((res = select(fd+1, NULL, (int*) &sfds, NULL, &tv)) > 0)
291  break;
292 #else
293  if ((res = select(fd+1, NULL, &sfds, NULL, &tv)) > 0)
294  break;
295 #endif
296  if (res == 0) /* timeout */
297  DBUG_RETURN(-1);
298  now_time= my_time(0);
299  timeout-= (uint) (now_time - start_time);
300  if (errno != EINTR || (int) timeout <= 0)
301  DBUG_RETURN(-1);
302  }
303 
304  /*
305  select() returned something more interesting than zero, let's
306  see if we have any errors. If the next two statements pass,
307  we've got an open socket!
308  */
309 
310  s_err=0;
311  if (getsockopt(fd, SOL_SOCKET, SO_ERROR, (char*) &s_err, &s_err_size) != 0)
312  DBUG_RETURN(-1);
313 
314  if (s_err)
315  { /* getsockopt could succeed */
316  errno = s_err;
317  DBUG_RETURN(-1); /* but return an error... */
318  }
319  DBUG_RETURN(0); /* ok */
320 #endif /* HAVE_POLL */
321 }
